Ali Golub
NYU Tisch Film and TV Class of ‘19
Apr 4

The College Admissions Process Has Fucked Up Origins

“We, the world, still have a lot to make up for when it comes to Jews” — NYU Local Writer Zoe Haylock

Congratulations Class of 2021. You did it. You’re in. You’re going to NYU and putting yourself into 300k+ dollars of debt. The hard part is over. You filled out the application, took all the standardized tests, wrote a personal essay, made teachers you barely know write a recommendation, did an interview, and now finally you’re in. You’re done (unless you’re going to grad school-haha suckers, film school is the best).

But before you start feeling too proud of yourself for getting through all of that, let’s just clarify one thing: that system only exists to keep Jews out. Or at least it did.

No, seriously. Back in the 1800s college was just something white wealthy Protestant men who went to boarding schools did. Finally around the early 1900s they finally started letting public school students in. (That’s right, if you went to public school you couldn’t go to college until the early 1900s-only 100 years ago. So the education system has always catered to the rich). Due to the large amount of students applying they needed new ways to filter the qualified and unqualified. Thus, college entrance exams were born.

For a time, a high test score was the only thing you needed to apply and get into college (like today, obviously the higher the score the more likely of getting into a more selective school). This allowed people other than Christian white men to go to college-especially Jews. From 1900 to 1922 the number of Jews on Ivy campuses tripled to about 21 percent of the freshman class.

College administrators didn’t like that and neither did their wealthy alumni (aka donor base). One wrote to the Harvard president saying “there were Jews to the right of me, Jews to the left of me, in fact they were so obviously everywhere that instead of leaving the Yard with pleasant memories of the past I left with a feeling of utter disgust of the present and grave doubts about the future of my Alma Mater.” Ughhhhhhhhhhhhhh.

Alumni and WASPy students thought Jews were weak and nerdy, for lack of a better term, while the administrators knew Jewish parents didn’t have the kind of money to donate that the WASPs did (glad to see colleges being run like a business is not new). Harvard’s president at the time even once said that admitting too many Jews would ruin the school as “the summer hotel that is ruined by admitting Jews meets its fate . . . because they drive away the Gentiles, and then after the Gentiles have left, they leave also.” Hahahaha, fuck you Lawrence Lowell.

So Lowell and his contemporaries at Yale and Princeton decided they needed to come up with a way to keep Jews out. If Jews were always going to come out on top in academic merit, they would just change their definition of merit. All of sudden merit became character and colleges started to require personal essays, an interview, and even a photo (this also made enlisting legacies way easier-keeping out even more Jews). The application was expanded to contain questions like “Race and Color”, “Mother’s Maiden Name”, “Birthplace of Father”, and “Religious Preference” (sound familiar?). They might’ve well just asked “ARE YOU JEWISH????” at the top of every application.

This new system worked of course and Jewish enrollment went back down to about 7 percent, while legacy and athlete enrollment (“worthy and quality men” apparently) increased under this new system, regardless of how academically under qualified they were. Even today, a legacy applicant has a 23 percent higher chance of getting in than a non-legacy applicant.

This college admissions process is still alive and well and pretty much used by every college in the country, showing that we as a society will keep any fucked up system in place as long as it is sorta working and been in practice long enough (not that this should be news…). And it’s apparently still being used to keep quotas, only this time around the victims are Asians.

The only good thing in this story is that NYU was maybe the good guy for once. They began to attract the “most talented Jewish students”, who had been turned away from the Ivy League, apparently due to their lack of quotas (or more likely their lack of efficient quotas because anti-Semitism still definitely was/is a thing here) and let them attend. So yay NYU you’re not the guilty party this time! Enjoy that for once!

And to the future Class of 2022, just keep this in mind as you start applying in the fall: the system is fucked up and was designed to keep Christian white men at the top. Sweet dreams!
